children: The pleural space is the space between the visceral and parietal pleura, which cover the lung and the chest wall, respectively. The physiologic function of this space is not well understood, but it has been suggested that it helps maintain positive transpulmonary pressure, which prevents atelectasis. The two main abnormalities affecting the pleura result from the presence of either excess fluid (pleural effusion) or excess air (pneumothorax) in the pleural space.

Each year more than 1.5 million new cases of pleural effusion are diagnosed in the United States. Most effusions are benign; however, approximately 16% are secondary to malignancy. Heart failure, pneumonia, and malignancy are the most common etiologies in the United States. Normally the pleural space contains only a small amount of fluid (less than 15 mL). Pleural effusions result from conditions that affect the rate of fluid entry from pleural capillaries and the ability of lymphatics to absorb the fluid.
Heart failure, pneumonia, and malignancy are the most common causes of pleural effusion in the United States.

The cause of a pleural effusion is often suggested by patient history and physical examination. Symptoms typically include dyspnea, cough, and pleuritic chest pain. Elderly patients often present with atypical symptoms such as anemia, fatigue, and failure to thrive. Key questions include severity and duration of symptoms; constitutional symptoms such as fevers, night sweats, and weight loss; occupation; recent illness, injury, or travel; exposures (for example, asbestos); and medical history such as heart failure, previous surgeries, and medications. The chest examination may reveal dullness to percussion and diminished or absent fremitus and breath sounds if the effusion is larger than 300 mL. There are several other key physical examination findings that may suggest the cause of the effusion

A chest radiograph should be performed as the first test in an evaluation of a possible pleural effusion. The radiographic findings are variable, but abnormalities may be seen with as little as 200 mL on the posterior-anterior chest radiograph or 50 mL on the lateral view

Thoracic point-of-care ultrasonography is a helpful addition to chest radiography for identification of small effusions, particularly in patients who are semirecumbent, such as those who are critically ill
. This imaging allows estimation of the quantity of the fluid and determination of whether it is free-flowing or loculated (i.e., with septations)
. Ultrasonography is also associated with fewer complications when it is used to guide pleural procedures (such as thoracentesis).

The advantages of CT imaging with contrast include the ability to detect small amounts of pleural fluid; the assessment of coexisting intrathoracic abnormalities, such as pulmonary masses and malignant pleural disease; and identification of an empyema, as enhancement of the pleura around the fluid creates a lenticular-shaped opacity
A chest radiograph should be performed in the initial evaluation of possible pleural effusion.
Thoracic ultrasound can characterize pleural effusions, quantify volume, and decrease complications when used to guide pleural procedures.

Thoracic ultrasound is more sensitive than chest radiography for the diagnosis of effusion in semirecumbent or supine patients, such as those who are critically ill, and in those with small effusions.
Once a pleural effusion is identified, the next diagnostic test to consider is thoracentesis.

Indications include pleural effusion of unknown cause and greater than 1 cm of fluid thickness on ultrasound or lateral decubitus radiograph. Thoracentesis should be performed with ultrasound guidance, as this allows for both a greater success rate and a reduced risk for solid organ puncture and iatrogenic pneumothorax.
The first step in pleural fluid analysis is assessing the appearance of the pleural fluid

. The next step is to determine whether it is a transudate or exudate. Transudates are the result of an imbalance between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures, as occurs with heart failure and cirrhosis. Exudates are the result of inflammation causing increased capillary permeability, impaired drainage by lymphatics, or both. There are many causes of exudative effusions, but the most common are infection and malignancy. Differentiation is commonly made using Light's criteria

. These criteria are very sensitive for exudates—however, they are less specific, and approximately 25% of transudates are misclassified as exudates. In patients who have underlying heart failure and are receiving diuretics, a serum NT-pro B-type natriuretic peptide of greater than 1500 pg/mL is suggestive of a cardiac etiology for the effusion. Checking pleural fluid cholesterol is another accurate method for classifying an effusion as an exudate. Exudative and transudative effusions have a wide range of causes

In addition to characterizing a pleural effusion as a transudate or exudate, other tests are often performed on the basis of clinical suspicion. If infection is suspected, pH, glucose, cell count, Gram stain, and aerobic and anaerobic cultures should be performed. If malignancy is suspected, cytological analysis of fluid should be performed.

Cell counts are useful for determining the cause of a pleural effusion—however, they are not disease-specific. Neutrophil-predominant effusions are secondary to an acute process such as pneumonia (parapneumonic effusion) or pulmonary embolus. Lymphocyte predominance (more than 50%) is common in chronic effusions. The most common causes worldwide of lymphocyte-predominant effusions are tuberculosis and cancer. An effusion with greater than 10% eosinophils is most commonly caused by current or recent air or blood in the pleural space and is a nonspecific finding

Pleural fluid acidosis (pH less than 7.3) is nonspecific and occurs in malignant effusions, complicated parapneumonic effusions, esophageal rupture, and inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid and lupus pleuritis. A pH less than 7.2 in a parapneumonic effusion indicates that a complicated pleural effusion is present and tube thoracostomy drainage is needed. Glucose normally diffuses freely across the pleural membrane. A pleural glucose concentration of less than 60 mg/dL (3.33 mmol/L) narrows the differential significantly and suggests that the effusion is secondary to malignancy, empyema or complicated parapneumonic effusion, tuberculosis, esophageal rupture, or rheumatoid or lupus pleuritis.

Pleural fluid amylase concentration should be checked if there is concern that the effusion may be a result of pancreatitis or esophageal rupture. Pleural fluid amylase greater than the upper limit of normal for serum amylase or a pleural fluid to serum amylase ratio greater than 1.0 are indicative of pancreatitis or esophageal rupture.

Pleural fluid triglycerides elevated above 110 mg/dL (1.24 mmol/L) support the diagnosis of chylothorax. If the triglyceride level is between 50 and 110 mg/dL (0.56 and 1.24 mmol/L), the presence of chylomicrons should be checked. A true chylothorax results from a disruption of the thoracic duct and is usually the result of thoracic surgery or trauma. Other causes include malignancy (lymphoma), tuberculosis, and lymphatic malformations.

The diagnosis of tuberculosis should be considered in a patient with a lymphocyte-predominant exudative effusion of unclear cause—however, confirming the diagnosis may be challenging. An acid-fast smear of pleural fluid has a sensitivity of less than 5%, and mycobacterial culture has a sensitivity of only 10% to 20% because of the low mycobacterial load. Adenosine deaminase is an enzyme present in lymphocytes that is elevated in most tuberculous pleural effusions (sensitivity, 90%). In countries with a low incidence of tuberculosis, testing for adenosine deaminase can be useful because a negative test helps to exclude tuberculosis. Pleural biopsy is useful for histology and is also the most likely source to yield a positive mycobacterial culture (greater than 70%).

Cytologic examination of pleural fluid has an average sensitivity of 60%. Sensitivity is slightly higher in adenocarcinoma (79%) and significantly lower in mesothelioma (6%), squamous cell carcinoma (14%), and lymphoma (40%). There is minimal benefit to obtaining and sending more than two fluid samples. If cytology is negative and malignancy is still suspected, pleural biopsy under direct visualization—known as thoracoscopy—may be the next step in evaluation. This procedure has a diagnostic sensitivity for malignant disease of greater than 90%. Closed pleural biopsy provides only a random sample of pleural tissue without visualization of pleural abnormalities. It is less sensitive than fluid cytology and has been replaced by thoracoscopy in the diagnostic evaluation of pleural malignancy.

A pleural effusion associated with a bacterial pneumonia is called a parapneumonic effusion. It can be uncomplicated (sterile and free flowing) or complicated (either infected or loculated). Uncomplicated effusions are typically small and resolve on their own with treatment of the pneumonia. Complicated parapneumonic effusions occur with significant inflammation or when bacteria invade the pleural space. An empyema is defined as a bacterial infection of the pleural space, which results in purulent fluid or a positive Gram stain. Pleural fluid cultures identify pathogens in only 60% of cases. If infection is suspected, culture bottles should be inoculated at the bedside to increase yield. Drainage is required if there is a positive Gram stain or culture or when the pH is less than 7.2. are more prevalent in nosocomial empyema. Anaerobic bacteria are cultured in greater than 20% of pleural space infections and may be a result of the common association with aspiration or the anaerobic environment of the pleural space. Polymicrobial infections are common, and empiric antibiotic regimens before obtaining culture results should include coverage for anaerobes.

Complicated parapneumonic effusions and empyema require drainage. Options for drainage include early surgical intervention via video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery and chest tube drainage with or without the combined use of intrapleural fibrinolytics (streptokinase, urokinase, tissue plasminogen activator) and a mucolytic agent (deoxyribonuclease, or DNase). There is controversy regarding which approach is best, and this question is under investigation. A multidisciplinary discussion should take place to help inform this decision.

The diagnosis of a malignant pleural effusion signifies advanced disease and overall poor prognosis (usually 4-7 months from the time of diagnosis). In these cases, the goal of management is the relief of symptoms. Several therapeutic options exist, and treatment decisions should be based on symptoms, prognosis, degree of anticipated lung reexpansion, and patient performance status. Repeat therapeutic thoracentesis is appropriate for patients with poor prognosis (less than 3 months) and slow reaccumulation of fluid. Patients with rapid reaccumulation of fluid and dyspnea should be offered more definitive management. Indwelling pleural catheters with intermittent outpatient drainage provide significant symptom relief, and approximately 50% of patients achieve spontaneous pleurodesis after 6 to 8 weeks. Chemical pleurodesis refers to obliteration of the pleural space with a sclerosing agent (typically talc). Talc can be introduced through a thoracostomy tube (talc slurry) or during a thoracoscopy (talc poudrage). Talc pleurodesis is very effective, with a success rate of 60% to 90%, depending on the degree of lung reexpansion.

Recurrent benign pleural effusions portend a poor prognosis, as they are a marker of worsening of the underlying disease. Mortality rates of 50% in one year have been associated with effusions secondary to heart failure, 46% in those with kidney failure, and 25% in those with liver failure. As such, refractory benign effusions also deserve prompt attention. If diagnostic uncertainty persists, additional evaluation with imaging (chest CT with contrast) and possible thoracoscopy should be considered. Options for management include tunneled pleural catheters, pleurodesis, or both after careful discussion with a multidisciplinary team.

Pneumothorax is defined as air in the pleural space, which can occur spontaneously or as a result of trauma or a procedural complication. A primary spontaneous pneumothorax (PSP) occurs in someone without known underlying lung disease. A secondary spontaneous pneumothorax (SSP) occurs in someone with a known underlying lung disease such as COPD. Risk for recurrence for PSP is 23% to 50% over the course of 1 to 5 years and greater than 50% over the course of 1 to 3 years in those with SSP. Risk factors for pneumothorax are listed in

Symptoms include sudden onset of dyspnea and sharp pleuritic chest pain. The symptoms are typically more severe with SSP because patients have less respiratory reserve. Physical examination findings can be subtle but usually reveal reduced lung expansion, hyperresonance to percussion, and diminished breath sounds on the side of the pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax should be suspected in patients presenting with significant cardiorespiratory distress (worsening dyspnea, hypotension, absent breath sounds on one side, tracheal deviation, and distended neck veins).

A chest radiograph is an appropriate initial test and can confirm the diagnosis and determine the size of the pneumothorax. If the lung margin is greater than 2 cm away from the chest wall at the level of the hilum, it is considered a large pneumothorax

. CT is the most sensitive imaging modality for small pneumothoraces and is particularly useful in patients with bullous emphysema. Ultrasound can also be helpful in the diagnosis of pneumothorax, with the presence of lung sliding (see
) indicating no pneumothorax at that specific location and the presence of a lung point (

Management of pneumothorax is driven by clinical symptoms. A tension pneumothorax (large and hemodynamically significant) should be managed by emergent needle thoracostomy followed by thoracostomy tube placement and hospitalization. Observation alone has been shown to be safe for small pneumothoraces in patients with minimal symptoms

Recurrence prevention is recommended after the second episode of pneumothorax on the ipsilateral side in PSP and after the first occurrence in SSP. Patients should be encouraged to stop smoking; the lifetime incidence rates for PSP are much higher in men who are lifelong heavy smokers than in men who have never smoked (12% vs 0.1%). Intervention to prevent recurrence includes both chemical and mechanical pleurodesis. Air travel should be avoided until complete resolution of the pneumothorax, and scuba diving is not recommended unless definitive therapy such as surgical pleurectomy has been applied.

children: Key Physical Examination Findings in the Evaluation of a Pleural Effusion
Heart failure, nephrotic syndrome, cirrhosis, hypoalbuminemia
Calf or thigh swelling, erythema, edema, tenderness
Accentuated cardiac pulmonic sound, right ventricular heave

title.__html: Pleural Fluid Characteristics and Diagnostic Considerations

children: Pleural Fluid Characteristics and Diagnostic Considerations
Malignancy, pulmonary embolus, trauma, pneumonia, benign asbestos pleural effusion
Hematocrit: if >50% of the serum, it is a hemothorax; consider aortic rupture, myocardial rupture, and injuries to hilar structures, lung parenchyma, and intercostal vessels
Chylothorax (most commonly seen after trauma or in patients with lymphoma) or cholesterol effusion (associated with tuberculosis and rheumatoid arthritis)
pH, glucose, cell count, gram stain, aerobic and anaerobic cultures
Combined Light's criteria (1 or more of the following 3):
Ratio of pleural fluid protein to serum protein level >0.5
Ratio of pleural fluid LDH level to serum LDH level >0.6
Pleural-fluid LDH level >2/3 the upper limit of normal for serum LDH
Ratio of pleural-fluid cholesterol to serum cholesterol >0.3
